Show some love to our Medium account     Current Events  Forum Upgrades: Forum Explorer & Impact Estimations With most public discussions of MakerDAO and its governance centered around our forums, forum management and ease of use are increasingly important, especially as the number of ecosystem participants and contributors grows. Two initiatives aim to make it easier to browse and search the forum and help forum-goers decide which governance items may be worth spending more time investigating.  Introducing Forum Explorer  The Forum Explorer is a Discourse plugin added to the forum by GovAlpha to make it easier to search through the forums using accessible filters and custom queries.  Main Features  Forum admins can create custom queries complete with titles and descriptions. This enables us to surface key forum content more effectively than the default tools. Users can apply tag and category filters using the sidebar at the left, allowing more natural exploration and discoverability of relevant content. Users can search/filter boxes for posts, tags, and categories within this UI to further aid navigation to relevant content.  Here at GovComms, we make heavy use of Forum Explorer every time we put together one of these publications.  Introducing Impact Estimations  Last week, GovAlpha announced that they are investigating applying impact estimations to active MIPs and Signal Requests. In an impact estimation, a GovAlpha team member will assign a value—Likely Low Impact, Likely Medium Impact, Likely High Impact—to each new governance item posted to the forum. These estimations aim to give forum users a sense of how important and impactful new governance items are likely to be and help readers decide how much time to spend engaging with each one.  More Details About Impact Estimation Values  Likely High Impact  Anything that adds concretely identifiable risk to the Maker Protocol Anything the DAO is doing for the first time Anything that removes a non-trivial amount of money from the surplus buffer Core Unit onboarding and offboarding Anything that permanently changes governance processes or structures within MakerDAO  Likely Medium-Impact  Items that may lead to later decisions that add risk or deplete the surplus buffer Anything that removes a trivial amount of money from the surplus buffer  Likely Low Impact  Minor wording changes and/or fixes to existing MIPs    Look for impact tags on forum posts about RFC MIPs and Signal Requests. They will also be included in the governance tracker spreadsheet.   This Week in Governance  Maker Improvement Proposals (MIPs) Weekly MIPs Update #81 by @blimpa  952×714 28 KB  Two Short Ratification Polls (three-day polls for proposals that enter the Weekly Cycle) went up on March 28 and closed on March 31. Both proposals passed—the MIP62 amendments have been merged. The SPF disbursement will go into an executive as soon as the multisig details have been sorted out.  As per MIP4c3, MIP4c3-SP3: Amend MIP64 to Allow More Flexibility in Scope is a weekly-cycle sub proposal that requires a Signal Request passing with at least 51% before being promoted on-chain. That Signal Request is now live and will run for one week. Please go vote!   The April Formal Submission Window is now open and will remain so until EOD Wednesday 6. This is relevant for proposals that enter the Monthly Governance Cycle and have fulfilled their Feedback Period and complied with their Frozen Period—and are eligible to enter the April cycle.    RFC and FS Dates for reference and existing proposals can be seen on this proposal tracker (WIP). DAI won't die.   10:57 PM - 2 Apr 2022           34                1             Forum Insight Penn Blockchain Delegate Platform Penn Blockchain, a student-run blockchain organization at The University of Pennsylvania, has officially published its delegate platform to the forum. Penn Blockchain hopes to use its wide-ranging experience in crypto governance to help Maker make the best decisions for our protocol. Members are involved in governance initiatives for several popular protocols they have delegations for, including Aave, Compound, Uniswap, and DyDx. Proposal author @juanbug is currently working with us internally to investigate on-chain strategies for increasing treasury and liquidity for Dai. Core Values  Broadcast Maker to not only Penn but also the greater university community Help Maker through its Layer-2 and cross-network integrations Advise and support Maker with treasury management initiatives Educate and teach students about the Maker project, expand its connections with university teams, and provide opportunities for future collaboration  [Discussion] Rethinking budgeting for CUs Core Unit budgeting has been a hot topic on the forums in recent weeks. The latest addition to the discussion comes from Recognized Delegate Justin Case, who analyzes the topic into its parts and explores which parts may be most valuable to focus on. @JustinCase begins by identifying the different elements any budget process must balance:  Ease of comparing different budgets to each other Governance overhead of evaluating a growing number of budgets The ability to make meaningful changes to a budget vs. the need to avoid micromanagement and respect CU autonomy The need for oversight vs. work demand on reporting and evaluation The risk of providing CUs with too many funds that remain unused and unreturned vs. keeping efficient operations and the need for frequent additional budget requests Over- or underutilization of a given core unit given their budget, especially for core units that primarily serve other core units  Next, Case focuses on two areas where improvement can encourage better budget discipline and help ensure resources are spent on more valuable initiatives. Indirect Financing Indirectly financing some Core Units—meaning they will not receive a direct budget but will be funded on an as-needed basis—will help ensure that only the community’s services are funded. Competition Next, Case describes an interesting idea for introducing natural competition to exert downward pressure on budget proposals. By adding redundancy to the organization of Core Units, namely by establishing parallel CUs in the same field while also ensuring that neither CU can monopolize all the work, CUs will compete to provide the best services to the DAO at the lowest cost. Like any proposal, this one comes with its advantages and disadvantages. Pros  Greater focus on objectives as they are now set at the protocol level. Increased cost control because Core Units will have to be attractive to win bids for work. Better redundancy because other Core Units can step up and replace others if they cease to function. Less focus on micromanaging Core Units and detailed budget proposals. Increased Core Unit autonomy.  Cons  Increased governance overhead in designing objectives. With individual Core Units reduced in size, they may be less capable of independently moving the protocol forward. Less security for Core Units may lead to detachment from the protocol.  Discussion on this topic is already heating up. Share your input here.
